Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A house has structural wood damage from termites, and the carpenter needs to provide an urgent repair plan
Story: I stood in the living room, the scent of old wood and dust thick in the air. My stepmother’s voice echoed from the kitchen, reminding me again how important it was to keep the family home just as it had always been. “Your father would want you to respect our traditions,” she said, her eyes lingering on the carved banister, worn smooth by generations. But as a carpenter, I couldn’t ignore the deep grooves and hollow sounds beneath my knuckles—termites had eaten away at the very bones of the house. The staircase, the window frames, even the beloved old mantelpiece were all at risk. My professional instinct screamed for urgent action: replace the damaged wood, modernize where needed, ensure safety. Yet, every suggestion I made to my family was met with resistance. They wanted restoration, not replacement, clinging to every original board as if it were sacred. I felt torn, caught between the duty to protect my family’s safety and the pressure to honor their wishes. My hands, skilled at building and mending, trembled as I weighed the cost of each choice, knowing that whatever I decided, something precious would be lost.
